Description: Small mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; simplified back, with clypeus, prothorax and elytra marked; at side, legs not understood, represented by broad incised lines forming a triangle, but not cut away; underside with hieroglyphic inscription, crudely incised, with neb-basket sign surmounted by owl and sun-disc (shape of an egg though) to left; longitudinally pierced; in bright blue fine paste; surface quite eroded.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The owl sign is often associated on Naukratite scarabs and scaraboids with solar symbols (see example of an owl between an obelisk and sun-disk in Gorton 1996, 103, no. 84) or other sacred signs (Maat feather, ankh sign: Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, 42; Gorton 1996, 104). Though the hieroglyphic signs have often just some magical value, it seems plausible that this is a cryptographic reading for the name of Amun-Ra. The scarab was attributed to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, notably on Punic sites and in the Levant (Gorton 1996, 112-114, type XXXI, subtype 20-25, see particularly 23 for this piece). It fits, however, better Gorton's Type XXX A (see notably type XXX A1 from Carthage). For a similar association of signs on other scarabs from Naukratis: see BM 1886,0401.1667 and Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 88.859. Variant of the same motif on scarabs and scaraboids from the Scarab Factory (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming): Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 99-104; Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, 42. This scarab in Egyptian blue was analysed by XRF with list of chemical elements (Vandiver 1983, C51, 285-5-685). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Vandiver, P.B.F.1983, ‘Appendices’, in A. Kaczmarczyk and R.E.M. Hedges (eds), Ancient Egyptian Faience, Warminster, A1–D4. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 101) (same type)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 113, Type XXXI 23)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.45) (phase 3)
